bibl.title: Fletcher Decker v. State of Washington
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: BE IT REMEMBERED, That on this 6th day of Aug. A. D. 1921, before me, a United States Commissioner for the said Western District of Washington, Northern Division, personally came Fletcher Decker, Principal and 5 Liberty Bonds of $100.00 each by Ruth Green, as sureties and jointly and severally acknowledged themselves to owe the United States of America the sum of five hundred dollars, to be levied on their goods and chattels, lands and tenements, if default be made in the condition following, to-wit:

THE CONDITION of this Recognizance is such, that if the said Fletcher Decker shall personally appear before me, a United States Commissioner as aforesaid, at my office, 316 Marion Building, in the City of Seattle, and District aforesaid, on the 18th day of August, A. D. 1921, at 11 o'clock A. M. and from time to time thereafter, to which the case may be continued, then and there to answer the charge of having, on or about the 15th day of November, A. D. 1915, within said District, in violation of Section 5270 R. S. of the Revised Statutes of the United States, unlawfully steal; take and convey away flax, and then and there abide the order of the said Commissioner, and not depart from said District without leaves, then this Recognizance to be void, otherwise to remain in full forces and virtue.
Witness: Taken and acknowledged before me on the day and year first above written.
Robt. W. McClelland, United States Commissioner as aforesaid
